{{NCAAIceHockeyTeamSeason |Image = |ImageSize = |Season = [[2009â10 NCAA Division I women's ice hockey season|2009â10]] |Team = Cornell Big Red |Sex = women |Conference = Eastern College Athletic Conference |ShortConference = ECAC |ConferenceRank =1 |Poll#1 = USA Today/USA Hockey Magazine |Poll#1Rank = 2 |Poll#2 = USCHO.com/CBS College Sports |Poll#2Rank = 6 |Record = 17-8-6 |HomeRecord = |RoadRecord = |NeutralRecord = |HeadCoach = Doug Derraugh |AsstCoach1= Danielle Bilodeau |AsstCoach2= Edith Zimmering |AsstCoach3= |Captain = Kelly McGinty |AltCaptain = |Arena = [[Lynah Rink]] |Champion = ECAC Regular season champions
ECAC Tournament champions |NCAATourney = NCAA Frozen Four |NCAATourneyResult = Runner-up, Lost 3-2 (OT) to Minnesota Duluth }} The '''2009â10 Cornell Big Red women's ice hockey team''' represented [[Cornell University]] in the [[2009â10 NCAA Division I women's hockey season]]. The Big Red were coached by Doug Derraugh and assisted by Dani Bilodeau and Edith Zimmering. The Big Red were a member of the [[Eastern College Athletic Conference]] and would become one of the most improved teams in the NCAA after the 2009-10 campaign. At the end of the 2008-09 season, the Big Red won 12 contests. The Big Red won 21 games, an improvement of nine wins. The Big Red were second in the USA Today poll, were 17-8-6 overall and posted a 14-2-6 record in ECAC Hockey this season. All of their home games will be played at Lynah Rink. *''If you are looking for live score updates you can check the cornell big red sitehttp://cornellbigred.com/index.aspx?tab=icehockey2&path=whockey or you can check the home game live blog for in depth details and up-to-the-minute updates for each home game. http://livestats.internetconsult.com/cornell/whockey/'' ==Offseason== * August 17: A trio of Big Red players were selected to the Canadian U22 National Team. Sophomore [[Catherine White (ice hockey)|Catherine White]] and incoming freshmen [[Lauriane Rougeau]] and Laura Fortino were selected among the 23-player roster. Chelsea Karpenko participated at the camp but was not named to the team. http://www.ecachockey.com/women/members/cornell/20091708_CornellCanadaU22Roster * Sept. 4: [[Rebecca Johnston]] has scored five goals in two games, including her first career hat trick, in the 2009 Canada Cup. http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/hockey/Johnston-tweaks-her-game_-hits-her-stride-with-Canadian-women_s-hockey-team-57031972.html ==Exhibition== {|class="wikitable" width="80%" |- align="center" style="background:red;color:white;" | '''Date''' || '''Opponent''' || '''Location''' || '''Score''' |- align="center" bgcolor="" | October 18 || [[Toronto Aeros]] || Lynah Rink || 5-5http://cornellbigred.com/news/2009/10/18/WICE_1018090035.aspx |} ==Regular season== * Oct 31: The Cornell women's hockey team defeated its second straight ranked opponent with a 4-3 victory over #9 Harvard on Saturday afternoon. The win gives the Big Red its first ever weekend sweep against Dartmouth and Harvard after Cornell's 3-0 win against Dartmouth.http://www.ecachockey.com/women/2009-10/Game_Stories/20093110_Cornell_Harvard * February 17: Laura Fortino, Lauriane Rougeau and Catherine White are among one of forty five nominees for the [[Patty Kazmaier Memorial Award]]. http://www.usahockey.com/patty_kazmaier/default.aspx?NAV=AF&id=280824&DetailedNews=yes * March 4: Catherine White has been named a finalist for the ECAC Player of the Year Award. http://dartmouthsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=48905&SPID=4726&DB_OEM_ID=11600&ATCLID=204901123 * March 6: ECAC Hockey announced that Catherine White has been awarded the Player of the Year award. White led the ECAC in assists with 24.http://www.ecachockey.com/women/2009-10/Weekly_Awards/20100603_W_Player_of_Yr_Winner ===Standings=== {{2009â10 ECAC Hockey standings (women)|team = COR}} 7 || 417 || 11 || 5 || 2 || 0 || 138 || .926 |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Katie Wilson || || || || || || || || |} ==Postseason== * March 7: Sophomore Kendice Ogilvie beat Clarkson goaltender Lauren Dahm at 7:52 mark in overtime. With the victory, Cornell wins its first ECAC Tournament, and earns its first trip to the NCAA Frozen Four.http://www.cornellbigred.com/news/2010/3/7/WICE_0307100425.aspx ===NCAA Tournament=== * On March 13, 2010, Cornell defeated the [[Harvard Crimson women's ice hockey]] program by a score of 6-2http://www.cornellbigred.com/news/2010/3/13/WICE_0313103301.aspx to earn its first ever trip to the NCAA Frozen Four. * March 21: Cornell goaltender Amanda Mazzotta set a record for most saves in an NCAA Championship game with 61 saves. The former record holder was Bulldog goaltender Patricia Sautter who had 41 saves in 2003.http://www.umdbulldogs.com/teams-womens-hockey.php?id=4999&page=news ==Awards and honors== * Doug Derragh,
